title: Albrecht von Hagen
text:
Albrecht von Hagen (11 March 1904 – 8 August 1944) was a German <a href="jurist">jurist</a> and a <a href="German%20resistance%20to%20Nazism">resistance</a> fighter in the time of the <a href="Third%20Reich">Third Reich</a>.
Life.
Von Hagen was born in <a href="%C5%81%C4%99gi%2C%20%C5%9Awidwin%20County">Langen</a>, <a href="Province%20of%20Pomerania%20%281815%E2%80%931945%29">Pomerania</a> (today Łęgi), on the manor of the original East Brandenburg-Pomeranian noble family in which he was rooted. After studying <a href="law">law</a> in <a href="Heidelberg">Heidelberg</a>, where he joined the Corps Saxo-Borussia Heidelberg (a <a href="Studentenverbindung">Studentenverbindung</a>), and in <a href="K%C3%B6nigsberg">Königsberg</a>, where he did his articling, he worked for the Osthilfe (a <a href="Weimar%20Republic">Weimar Republic</a> programme for developing the agrarian economy in eastern Germany) and a private <a href="bank">bank</a>. In 1935, he willingly took part in <a href="Wehrmacht">Wehrmacht</a> officer training courses, so that at the outbreak of the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>, he entered the military as a <a href="lieutenant">lieutenant</a> in the reserves. During an assignment in the Africa campaign, he got to know <a href="Claus%20Schenk%20von%20Stauffenberg">Claus Graf Schenk von Stauffenberg</a>, under whose influence he joined the resistance movement against the <a href="Nazis">Nazis</a>. The plotters got Von Hagen his post at the <a href="Oberkommando%20der%20Wehrmacht">Oberkommando der Wehrmacht</a>, where he was responsible for the courier service between military posts in Berlin and the so-called "Führerhauptquartier "<a href="Wolfsschanze">Wolfsschanze</a>"" (the Wolf's Lair, <a href="Hitler">Hitler</a>'s secret military headquarters near <a href="K%C4%99trzyn">Rastenburg</a> in <a href="East%20Prussia">East Prussia</a>). In May 1944, Hagen, together with Joachim Kuhn, arranged for the <a href="explosive">explosive</a> that was to be used in the attempt on Hitler's life. It was delivered through <a href="Hellmuth%20Stieff">Hellmuth Stieff</a> to Claus von Stauffenberg, who used it in the <a href="July%2020%20plot">attack on the Wolf's Lair</a> on 20 July 1944.
Von Hagen was arrested straightaway after the failed attempt to <a href="assassination">assassinate</a> the Führer. A few days later, his family was also taken into custody. On 8 August 1944, the "<a href="Volksgerichtshof">Volksgerichtshof</a>" sentenced him to death in a show trial, and Von Hagen was <a href="hanging">hanged</a> later the same day at <a href="Pl%C3%B6tzensee%20Prison">Plötzensee Prison</a> in Berlin. In his farewell letter to his wife is the line:
Von Hagen was a Knight of Honour of the <a href="Order%20of%20Saint%20John%20%28Bailiwick%20of%20Brandenburg%29">Order of St John</a>.
